notes.title: Protozoa: Asexual Reproduction & Conjugation in Paramecium
notes.content: Binary fission is the primary reproductive mode; ciliates also perform conjugation (exchange of micronuclei). Know autogamy vs. conjugation, and exam diagrams of nuclear events.
keyTakeaways: Binary fission increases numbers; conjugation restores vitality and genetic variation.
Macronucleus controls metabolism; micronuclei handle heredity and meiosis.
Typical exam asks: steps of conjugation with labeled diagram.

notes.title: Protozoa: Contractile Vacuole & Osmoregulation
notes.content: Explain how contractile vacuole complex (CVC) maintains osmotic balance in freshwater protozoa; frequent MCQ hotspot.
keyTakeaways: CVC alternates filling and expulsion to prevent lysis in hypotonic media.
V-ATPase–rich membranes drive fluid accumulation; expulsion via fusion at plasma membrane.
Activity increases as external osmolarity decreases.

resources.title: PubMed Review — Osmoregulation and Contractile Vacuoles of Protozoa

notes.title: Porifera: Canal Systems (Ascon, Sycon, Leucon) & Spicules
notes.content: Trace water flow in the three canal types; identify spicule forms (calcareous/siliceous) and their secretion.
keyTakeaways: Leuconoid has highest surface area and efficiency.
Spicule type is a taxonomic character and shows skeletal support.
Typical exam: labeled flow path + spicule sketches.

notes.title: Cnidaria: Polymorphism & Coral Reefs (Ecology/Economy)
notes.content: Explain polyp–medusa polymorphism (e.g., Obelia, siphonophores) and coral reef importance, threats, and conservation.
keyTakeaways: Division of labor among zooids increases colony efficiency.
Reefs provide biodiversity, coastal protection, and fisheries value.
Ocean warming/acidification compromises calcification.

notes.title: Platyhelminthes: Parasitic Adaptations & Flame Cells
notes.content: Describe morphological and physiological adaptations of parasitic flatworms; protonephridia/flame cells for excretion.
keyTakeaways: Reduced sensory systems, strong adhesions, and complex life cycles aid parasitism.
Flame cells drive filtrate via cilia; osmoregulation critical in flatworms.
Common essay: life cycle and control of Fasciola hepatica.

notes.title: Annelida: Metamerism & Nephridia
notes.content: Define true segmentation and advantages (locomotion, redundancy); compare protonephridia vs. metanephridia.
keyTakeaways: Segmentation enables localized control and regeneration.
Nephridia maintain osmotic and nitrogen balance across segments.
Draw a typical earthworm nephridial system with labels.

notes.title: Arthropoda: Exoskeleton, Molting & Insect Leg Modifications
notes.content: Explain chitinous exoskeleton (protection/attachment, limits growth) and molting; classify leg types (cursorial, saltatorial, raptorial, natatorial, fossorial).
keyTakeaways: Exoskeleton requires ecdysis; hormones (ecdysone) regulate molting.
Leg morphology correlates with habitat and behavior; a frequent figure-based MCQ.
Crustaceans vs. insects: cuticle composition and calcification differ.

notes.title: Mollusca: Torsion in Gastropods & Shell/Foot Modifications
notes.content: Define torsion (90–180° rotation) and its consequences (mantle cavity anterior); relate to coiling and body-plan changes.
keyTakeaways: Torsion repositions anus and mantle; potential fouling mitigated by asymmetry.
Adaptive significance debated; cite classic and modern papers.
Know diagrams: pre-/post-torsion larva, adult mantle cavity.

resources.title: PMC — Evidence that Gastropod Torsion is Driven by Asymmetric Development

notes.title: Echinodermata: Water Vascular System & Tube Feet
notes.content: Structure (madreporite → stone canal → ring & radial canals → ampullae → tube feet) and functions (locomotion, feeding, respiration).
keyTakeaways: Unique coelomic hydraulic system; exam favorites: labeling & function.
Tube feet use adhesion (suction+mucus) and sensory roles.
Comparative note: variability among classes (asteroids, echinoids, holothurians).

notes.title: Chordate Origins & Amphioxus (Cephalochordata)
notes.content: Amphioxus exemplifies chordate hallmarks (notochord, dorsal nerve cord, pharyngeal slits, post-anal tail) and informs vertebrate origins.
keyTakeaways: Used as a model for ancestral chordate body plan and genomics.
Amphioxus retains notochord in adults; lacks cranium and vertebrae.
Recent genomes refine cephalochordate phylogeny and regulatory evolution.

notes.title: Hemichordata vs. Chordata
notes.content: Contrast hemichordate traits (stomochord, pharyngeal slits) with chordates; clarify evolutionary relationships.
keyTakeaways: Stomochord ≠ notochord; shared features reflect deuterostome ancestry.
Common exam: table of differences + examples (Acorn worms, Pterobranchs).

notes.title: Vertebrate Circulatory System: Evolution of the Heart
notes.content: Trace evolutionary transition from single circulation (fish) to double circulation (birds/mammals); aortic arch patterns.
keyTakeaways: Partitioning increases oxygenation efficiency; relates to endothermy.
Know representative heart diagrams (2-, 3-, 3.5-, 4-chambered).

resources.title: OpenStax Biology 2e — Circulatory Systems in Animals

notes.title: Kidney & Nephron (Mammals) + Urea Cycle (Liver)
notes.content: Describe nephron structure and urine formation; link hepatic urea cycle converting ammonia → urea → renal excretion.
keyTakeaways: RAAS and ADH regulate fluid/electrolyte balance.
Clinical angle: urea cycle disorders cause hyperammonemia.
Exam often integrates liver–kidney physiology.

notes.title: Respiration: Reptiles vs. Birds vs. Mammals
notes.content: Compare lung structure (faveoli in reptiles; parabronchi/air sacs in birds; alveoli in mammals) and gas-exchange strategies.
keyTakeaways: Birds have unidirectional airflow and cross-current exchange; highest efficiency.
Mammals use alveolar tidal ventilation; reptiles use aspiration pump with less subdivision.
Name key structures in labeled diagrams.

notes.title: Aves: Flight Adaptations & Migration
notes.content: Skeletal (keeled sternum), muscular (powerful pectorals), respiratory (air sacs), and feather adaptations; migration drivers and navigation.
keyTakeaways: Weight reduction + power generation underpin flight.
Migration involves photoperiod, geomagnetic cues, and wind patterns.
Common short note: advantages of air sacs.

resources.title: Cornell Lab — Bird Migration (All About Birds)

notes.title: Mammals: Placenta & Types of Placentation
notes.content: Structure–function of placenta; classify placentation (epitheliochorial, endotheliochorial, hemochorial).
keyTakeaways: Maternal–fetal interface varies by group; affects antibody transfer.
Placental hormones support gestation; clinical correlations in humans.

notes.title: Mammalian Dentition
notes.content: Tooth formulas, heterodonty, and dietary adaptations (carnivore vs. herbivore).
keyTakeaways: Incisor–canine–premolar–molar patterns correlate with feeding.
Know human dental formula and comparisons.

notes.title: Cell Biology: Membranes & Organelles (ER, Golgi, Mitochondria, Lysosomes)
notes.content: Describe fluid mosaic model and organelle roles; link to secretion and energy metabolism.
keyTakeaways: ER/Golgi handle protein processing; mitochondria power ATP; lysosomes for autophagy.
Common MCQ: organelle–function matching.

notes.title: DNA Replication, Transcription & Translation
notes.content: Semiconservative replication; central dogma; transcriptional control and ribosomal translation.
keyTakeaways: DNA polymerases need primers; proofreading affects mutation rate.
Transcription factors & promoters regulate gene expression.
Ribosomes read codons; wobble explains tRNA economy.

resources.title: OpenStax Biology 2e — From DNA to Protein

notes.title: Genetics: Mendel's Laws & Variations
notes.content: Law of segregation and independent assortment; extensions (incomplete dominance, codominance, multiple alleles).
keyTakeaways: Use Punnett squares & probability; watch for non-Mendelian patterns.
Sex linkage affects phenotype ratios.

resources.title: Khan Academy — Variations on Mendel's Laws

notes.title: Linkage, Crossing Over & Mapping
notes.content: Explain linked genes, recombination frequency, and map unit (cM); typical numerical problems.
keyTakeaways: RF ≈ map distance for small distances; double crossovers complicate estimates.
Test cross setups are standard exam items.

notes.title: Sex-Linked Inheritance & X-Linked Disorders
notes.content: Patterns of X-linked recessive/dominant traits; pedigree analysis.
keyTakeaways: Males hemizygous for X; carrier females influence transmission.
Worked examples with Punnett squares are essential.

notes.title: Hardy–Weinberg Equilibrium (HWE)
notes.content: Population genetics null model; conditions and p² + 2pq + q² calculations with applications.
keyTakeaways: Use HWE to detect evolution (selection, drift, migration, nonrandom mating).
Exam staples: carrier frequency, allele frequency, and deviation tests.

notes.title: Evolution: Darwin vs. Lamarck & Natural Selection
notes.content: Contrast mechanisms; articulate Darwin's evidence and the modern synthesis.
keyTakeaways: Natural selection acts on heritable variation; Lamarckian inheritance rejected (with rare epigenetic caveats).
Be ready to write short critical essays with examples.

notes.title: Biogeochemical Cycles (Nitrogen, Phosphorus) & Food Webs
notes.content: Cycle components and human impacts; distinguish food chains vs. web; sedimentary vs. gaseous cycles.
keyTakeaways: Nitrogen fixation/nitrification/denitrification pathways are common MCQs.
Food webs better reflect ecosystem stability than simple chains.

notes.title: Pond Ecosystem: Structure & Energy Flow
notes.content: Abiotic/biotic components; producers→consumers→decomposers; classic short essay with diagram.
keyTakeaways: Stratification and nutrient cycling define productivity.
Decomposers close the loop; energy flow is unidirectional.

notes.title: Applied Zoology & Parasitology: Protozoan & Vector-Borne Diseases
notes.content: Medical importance of protozoa (malaria, leishmaniasis, amebiasis) and vector control (Aedes, Anopheles).
keyTakeaways: Life cycles guide control strategies (break transmission).
Integrated Vector Management (IVM) combines environmental, biological, and chemical tools.

notes.title: Climate Change & Zoology: Greenhouse Effect and Ocean Acidification (Impacts on Animals)
notes.content: Summarize greenhouse effect and CO₂ trends; ecological impacts on calcifiers (molluscs, corals) and food webs.
keyTakeaways: Rising CO₂ lowers ocean pH, reducing carbonate availability for shells.
Use recent, authoritative data sources (NOAA, IPCC) in answers.

resources.title: NOAA — Basics of the Carbon Cycle & Greenhouse Effect
